ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: some asynchronous components such as giving a presentation on voicethread and take home exams, but mostly synchronous virtual discussion
Synchronous zoom meeting every week day
Nothing else.
Coffee chats and other engaging events with Italian department. Movies.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Deeper understanding of Italian grammar and concepts covered in the previous levels, but on a much greater level with a greater emphasis on culture and societal issues.
reviewed grammar learned in L1 and L2. read literature and learned about italian culture
Italian language development and culture
I became much more comfortable speaking Italian, and feel like i am fully conversational at this point.
Better understanding of Italian language and culture. Skills for reading, listening and speaking.
Increased proficiency in language skills by reviewing and going into more detail with vocab and tenses.
A further understanding of italian language and culture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The daily interaction and exercises are very useful for learning the language. Ultimately I think the only weakness this semester is the fact that it had to be online, I feel like you learn a lot more for a foreign language when in-person.
Deborah is wonderful and learning italian culture is a lot of fun. It's better than just learning grammar and vocabulary.
Weakness is the course format is just going over practice exercises when I feel as though discussing more logistical aspects of material could be beneficial.
The strength of this course was the repeated engagement with the language and culture. It was also very easy to be engaged with the course even while virtual
The Professor -- Deborah Pellegrino -- is fantastic. She kept all the students engaged during an extremely difficult year, and made personal connections with each student.
Strengths: focus on culture and conversation, use of film and readings
The professor is a definite strength. Deborah is super helpful, kind, and just so lively. She makes going to class a blast.
I think this was the class that best replicated the in person experience.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There were practically no accommodations made aside from the course being over Zoom. I really felt like there could have been a greater effort made to supplement some of what was lost in the transition to Zoom.
I liked the breakout rooms to discuss in small groups with other classmates. It was difficult to jump in to volunteer to participate in the entire zoom room sometimes.
I thought it worked very well in response to the pandemic.
Virtual discussion worked very well, as everyone participated. Also discussing homework in breakout room was very helpful.
It is hard to foster participation in the virtual format and can be more difficult to have a natural conversation which made this difficult. The breakout rooms worked well. Overall great class.
I think everything worked pretty well.
Everything worked very well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Highly recommend! The Italian department is great and whether you are simply getting your L3 requirement or planning on continuing, Italian is a great option.

You would probably have to take it for the language requirement, but L3 was my favorite out of L1, L2, and L3. Honestly, it was pretty fun to go to every morning, but there are other courses I would prefer to spend my time taking.
I would recommend this course to another student if they were looking to fulfill their language requirement with Italian or just wanted to learn about the Italian language and culture
I would definitely recommend this course.
Yes. I love the Italian department. They try very hard to helo students grow, learn, and love the language.
Absolutely Deborah is a fantastic professor, and Italian is such a beautiful language. The class is great for reinforcing your skills on a daily basis.
Yes, it is the perfect culmination of the language requirement.
